From the erratic and orderly movements of the five planets onward, all illustrate how the inner stirring of hexagram images gives rise to fortune and misfortune externally. This chapter describes how proper union in gestation leads to such outcomes.

The first is concealment—none in the world know of it. The highest virtue acts through non-action, not seeking through scrutiny. The lesser virtue acts, and its function never ceases. When the upper is sealed, it is called "having"; when the lower is sealed, it is called "not having." The "not having" serves the "having," where the divine virtue resides above. These two apertures follow a method: metal and water also depend on each other. Know the white, guard the black, and the numinous clarity will come of itself. The white is the essence of metal; the black is the foundation of water. Water is the pivot of the Dao, and its number is called "one." It is the beginning of yin and yang, containing the yellow sprout within the mysterious. It is the master of the five metals, the river chariot of the north. chunks.original_text: 水数一而藏阳金，乃黑铅中之白银，世罕知之一即上德之坎也。 坎为上德，为有； 离为下德，为无。 离以翕受为用，绵绵若存，故其用不休，所以奉上也。 离汞须阳金而变化，金亦须离火而施精，故曰相须。 知水中有金，守其水则金自至，母隐子胎故也。 水数一而色黑，故曰守黑，明一者掩蔽之义。 此章言探药法度。 望之类白，造之则朱。 炼为表卫，白裹贞居。 方圆径寸，混而相拘。 先天地生，巍巍尊高。 旁有垣阙，状似蓬壶。 环匝#21关闭、四通踟局。 守御密固，关绝奸邪。 曲阁相通，以戒不虞。 可以无思，难以愁劳。 神黑满室，莫之能留。 守之者昌，失之者亡。 动静休息，常与人俱。 此章言圣胎成象，贵在护养。 是非历藏法，内视有所思。 履行步斗宿，六甲以曰辰。 阴道厌九一，浊乱弄玄胞。 食黑呜肠胃，吐正吸外邪#22。 昼夜不卧寐，肠呜#23未尝休。 身体以疲倦，恍惚状若痴。 百脉鼎沸驰，不得清澄居。 周回立坛宇，朝暮#24敬祭祠。 鬼物见形象，梦寐感慨之。 心欢而意悦#25，自谓必延期。 遽以夭命#26死，腐露其形骸。 举措辄有违，悖逆失枢机。 诸卫甚众多，千条有万余。 前却违黄老，曲折戾九都。 凡辞旨易晓，并不注，后准此。 明者省厥旨，旷然知所由。 勤而行之，夙夜不休。 服食三载，轻举远游。 入火不焦，入水不濡。 能存能亡，长乐无忧。 道成德就，潜伏埃时。 太乙乃召，移居中洲q功满上升，膺录受图。 此章言#27成道之事。 《火记》不虚作，演《易》以明之。 偃月法鼎炉，白虎为熬枢。 汞曰为流珠，青龙与之俱。 举东以合西，魂魄自相拘。 上弦兑数八、下弦亦如之。 两弦合其精，乾坤体乃成。 二八应一斤，《易》道正不倾。 金水同居，故坎月与白虎为熬#28枢； 木火同位，故流珠则青龙与俱。 举东合西者，以离受坎，复归纯乾之体。 ．自朔八曰而上弦，自望八曰而下弦，故曰二八应一斤，药之候也。 此章以四象论药物。 金入於猛火，色不夺精光。 自开辟以来，曰月不亏明，金不失其重，曰月形如常。 金本从月生，朔旦受曰符。 金反归其母，月晦曰相包。 隐藏其匡郭，沉沦於洞虚·。 金复其故性，威光鼎乃熹#29。 坎中金为真阳之药，入离火炼之，亘古不坏。 谕月之金精，受太阳符火，光明如常也。 上章总论四象。 此章独言金为真药。 子午数合三，戊己号称五。 三五既和谐，八石正纲纪。 呼吸相含育#30，伫恩#31涌为夫妇。 黄土金之父，流珠水之母。 水以土为鬼，土镇#32水不起。 朱雀为火精，执平调胜负。 水盛火消灭，俱死归厚土。 三性既会合#33，本性共宗祖。 子水一，午火二，戊己五，合为八石。 坎离、夫妇，有呼吸含育之象。 金、水、火三性归土，乃．合而为一。 本性共宗祖者，同出於一，复归於一也。 此章言交姤。 巨胜尚延年，还丹可入口。 金性不败朽，故为万物宝。 术士服食之，寿命得长久。 土游於四季，守界定规矩#34。 金砂入五内，雾散若风雨。 黑需#35达四肢，颜色悦泽好。 发白更生黑，齿落出旧所。 老翁复丁壮，老曰妪成诧女。 改形免世厄，号之曰真人。 此章言真阳之药，其劫如此。 胡粉投火中，色坏还为铅。

The number of water is one, concealing the yang within metal—this is the silver within black lead, a truth rarely known, for one is the supreme virtue of Kan. Kan is the supreme virtue, the realm of "having"; Li is the lesser virtue, the realm of "non-being." Li employs contraction and receptivity, existing ceaselessly like a continuous thread, thus its function never ceases, for it serves the supreme. Li-mercury requires yang-metal to transform, just as metal requires Li-fire to bestow its essence; hence they are said to be mutually dependent. Knowing that gold resides within water, guard the water and the gold will come of itself, for the mother conceals the child’s embryo. The number of water is one, and its color is black; thus it is called "guarding the black," for the meaning of "illuminating the one" lies in concealment. This chapter speaks of the method and measure for seeking the medicine.

Beheld, it resembles whiteness; refined, it becomes vermilion. When tempered, it forms the protective exterior, with purity dwelling within the white. Round or square, a mere inch in diameter, they merge and constrain one another. Born before heaven and earth, majestic and revered. Surrounding it are walls and gates, resembling Penglai’s isles. Encircled and sealed, its four paths are intricately arranged. Guarded with utmost secrecy, its gates bar all wickedness. Curved pavilions connect, ever vigilant against the unforeseen. Here, thought may cease, and sorrow finds no place. The numinous black fills the chamber, none can detain it. Those who guard it prosper; those who lose it perish. In movement and stillness, rest and activity, it ever accompanies the adept. This chapter speaks of the sacred embryo’s formation, emphasizing its nurturance and protection.

This is not the method of the hidden viscera; inner vision must have its focus. Treading the steps of the Dipper’s lodges, the six Jia follow the days and hours. The yin path suppresses nine with one, its turbid chaos disturbing the mysterious womb. Ingesting the black, the intestines rumble; exhaling the upright, inhaling external evil. Day and night without repose, the bowels never cease their murmuring. The body grows weary, the spirit dazed, as if in stupor. The hundred vessels boil and surge, unable to attain serene clarity. Circling, one erects altars and halls, offering morning and evening sacrifices. Ghostly forms appear, dreams stir with emotion. The heart rejoices, the mind delights, believing longevity assured. Yet suddenly, life is cut short, the body left to rot and decay. Every action runs counter, perverse and contrary to the pivot of the Dao. The methods are myriad, thousands upon tens of thousands. Advancing and retreating, they defy the Yellow and the Old, twisting and turning against the Nine Capitals.

The meaning of these words is plain and easily understood; no annotations are provided, and this shall serve as the standard hereafter. The wise will grasp their intent, suddenly perceiving the path’s origin. Practice diligently, day and night without rest. After three years of ingestion, one becomes light and roams afar. Entering fire, they are not scorched; entering water, they are not drenched. They can manifest or vanish at will, ever joyful and free from care. When the Dao is perfected and virtue accomplished, they remain concealed in the dust of the world. Then the Great One summons them, relocating them to the Central Isles. When merit is complete, they ascend, receiving the register and the chart. This chapter speaks of the attainment of the Dao.

The *Fire Record* is not written in vain; it expounds the *Yi* to clarify these truths. The crescent moon method employs the crucible and furnace, with the White Tiger as the pivot of refinement. Mercury is called the flowing pearl, accompanied by the Azure Dragon. Raising the east to meet the west, the hun and po naturally constrain one another. The upper crescent is Dui, numbered eight; the lower crescent is the same. When the essences of both crescents unite, the body of Qian and Kun is formed. Two eights correspond to one catty; the Dao of the *Yi* stands firm and unshaken. Metal and water dwell together, thus Kan’s moon and the White Tiger serve as the pivot of refinement. Wood and fire share the same position, thus the flowing pearl is accompanied by the Azure Dragon. Raising the east to meet the west means Li receiving Kan, returning to the pure body of Qian. From the new moon, eight days bring the upper crescent; from the full moon, eight days bring the lower crescent. Thus it is said that two eights correspond to one catty, the sign for the medicine. This chapter discusses the medicine in terms of the four images.

When metal enters fierce fire, its color does not fade nor its luster diminish. Since the beginning of creation, the sun and moon have never lost their brightness, nor has metal forfeited its weight; the sun and moon retain their usual forms. Metal is born from the moon, receiving the sun’s mandate at the new moon. Metal returns to its mother, and at the moon’s wane, they envelop one another. Concealing its frame, it sinks into the profound void. When metal regains its original nature, its majestic radiance illuminates the crucible. The gold within Kan is the medicine of true yang; refined in Li’s fire, it remains indestructible through the ages. This is likened to the moon’s metal essence receiving the fire of the great yang, its brilliance enduring as ever. The preceding chapter broadly discusses the four images; this chapter focuses solely on metal as the true medicine.

The numbers of zi and wu combine to make three; wu and ji are called five. When three and five harmonize, the eight minerals form the essential framework. Breathing nurtures their union, awaiting the surge that makes them husband and wife. Yellow earth is the father of metal; the flowing pearl is the mother of water. Water’s ghost is earth, which subdues water’s uprising. The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire, maintaining balance to determine victory or defeat. If water prevails, fire is extinguished, and both perish, returning to the fertile earth. When the three natures unite, their original nature shares a common ancestor. Zi-water is one, wu-fire is two, wu-ji is five, combining to form the eight minerals. Kan and Li, husband and wife, possess the image of breathing and nurturing union. When ice and snow meet warm broth, they dissolve into the Great Mystery.
Gold takes cinnabar as its master, harmonizing with mercury.
Transformation arises from their authenticity; beginning and end follow one another.
To become an immortal through ingestion, one must use substances of the same kind.
Plant millet with millet; hatch a chicken with its own egg.
Supporting nature with its kind, things form as easily as clay is shaped.
Can fish eyes be pearls? Can fleabane become a casket?
Like follows like; discordant matters cannot yield treasure.
Thus, swallows and sparrows do not birth phoenixes; foxes and hares do not nurse horses.
Water does not flow upward in flames; fire does not moisten downward in motion.

The world abounds with scholars, lofty and gifted with fine talent.
Yet, by chance, they fail to meet their destined path, wasting fire and squandering wealth.
Clinging to texts and following words, they recklessly impose their own interpretations.
Threads unravel without cause; measures and standards lose their grasp.
They smelt chalcanthite, mica, and alum-magnetite,
burn sulfur with camphorwood, and refine mercury with mud.
They smelt the five-stone bronze beneath the bellows, taking it as their pivot.
Yet, with natures of different kinds, how could they willingly unite in one body?
A thousand attempts lead to ten thousand failures; what they seek to transmute turns to folly.
From youth to white-haired age, doubt arises midway.
Turning from the Dao, they cling to delusion; stepping from the right path, they enter crooked trails.
Peering through a tube, their vision is narrow—how can they gauge what lies ahead?

Human nature possesses it: within separation, true yin is not true yang, and cannot transform.
How could disparate kinds merge with metal and stone? These are all external things.
As for the utmost sages, none surpass Fu Xi, who drew the Eight Trigrams and the Map of the Young Heavens.
King Wen, ancestor of emperors, structured the body and expounded the line texts.
Confucius, the near-sage hero, composed the *Ten Wings* to aid them.
These three lords were raised by Heaven, rising in succession to govern their times.
Though their excellence followed steps, their merits and virtues did not differ.
Their creations built upon one another, weighing and measuring with care.
The tangible is easy to estimate; the formless is hard to plan.
Their deeds set models for emulation, establishing classics for the world.
Without innate foresight, they awakened through their teachers.
Bright as one who parts the curtains and ascends the high terrace,
the *Fire Records* of six hundred chapters share the same aim.
Though the texts speak with solemnity, the world does not ponder deeply.
Tracing the source and flow, the hidden and manifest originally dwell together.

I humbly speak for the worthy—how dare I treat these writings lightly?
Holding my tongue, I wish to remain silent, yet cutting off the Dao invites punishment.
Pouring my thoughts onto bamboo and silk, I fear leaking Heaven’s tally.
Hesitant, I sigh, gazing up and down, stitching together this foolishness.

Refinement has its methods and standards; I cannot bear to lay them all bare.
I briefly outline the essentials; the branches and twigs will be seen in due course.

chunks.original_text: 举伏羲、文王、仲尼三圣，明此道之出於《易》象河图、洛书也。 震顺八数巽顺三数离顺七数坎顺一六数乾逆四数兑逆四数坤艮一顺一逆合皇极十五数魏先生谓天以河图授伏羲，伏羲错之以洛书之数，是为先天八卦。 以先天卦加河图，则药物火候昭然可见。 此圣人之所以见道，而达造化之机也。 夫以乾合离，是谓阳炉离宅於乾也； 以坤合坎，是谓阴鼎坎宅於坤也。 震与离会，龙从火裹出也。 兑与坎会，虎向水中生也。 亦二物总因儿产母之旨也。 至於月（缺）震而满乾，喊巽而没坤，此又分至火候之妙也。 天道浩荡，非《易》象不足以明之。 《易》道精微，非圣人不足以发之。 是道也，三君启之於前，魏君明之於后，信乎其出於河图矣。 以金为堤防，水入乃优游。 金数十有五，水数亦如之。 临炉定铢两，五分水有余。 二者以为真，金重如本初。 其三遂不入，火二与之俱。 三物相含受，变化状若神。 下有太阳黑，伏需须臾问。 先液而后凝，号曰黄舆焉。 岁月将欲讫，毁性伤寿年。 形体为灰土，状若明窗尘。 金水同居，举金则水入矣。 金九、水六，共十五数。 十五分中，水得六数，五分有余也。 金、水二者为真药，故曰二者以为真也。 夫木性资金情以为药，子藏母胞，故水随金入，发火於下，变化生焉。 水、金、火三物本者，性也。 制木以金，致金以水，炼金以火，木无所事，故言三物而不及木，其三遂不入也。 阳极故先液，阴生故后凝。 号曰黄舆者，天玄地黄，坤为地，为大舆故也。 修炼至此，阳极阴生，乾渐变坤也。 坤道穷极，龙战玄黄，形体为灰土，此第一真景象也。 此章言阳极阴生。 梼治并合之，驰入赤色门。 固塞其际会，务令致完坚。 炎火张於下，昼夜声正勤。 始文使可修，终竟武乃陈。 候视加谨慎，审察调寒温。 周旋十二节，节尽更亲观#42。 气索#43命将绝，休死亡魄魂。 色转更为紫，赫然成还丹。 粉提以一丸，刀圭最为神。 四象以合塞兑闭门，无思无为，以固际之。 及阴剥阳生，自坤化乾，乾为大赤，故曰驰入赤色门。 始文使可修者，为修丹进火是也。 火不可以遽进，始以文火调之，使刚柔不抗行，度其可修则进火，发火初温微是也。 始则发火以娠之，名曰野战； 中则文火以养之，名曰灌溉； 终则烈火以成之，名曰烹煎； 言进火之节也。 色转更为紫，赫然成还丹者，紫为乾，大赤之象，《益》之六三震之上爻也。 其究为健。 健，乾也，震变而为《乾》也。

The three sages—Fuxi, King Wen, and Confucius—reveal that this Dao emerges from the *Yi*’s images, the *Hetu* (River Chart), and the *Luoshu* (Luo Writing). Zhen aligns with the eight, Xun with the three, Li with the seven, Kan with the one and six, Qian in reverse with the four, Dui in reverse with the four, Kun and Gen with one forward and one reverse, together forming the imperial fifteen. Master Wei declared that Heaven bestowed the *Hetu* upon Fuxi, who then arranged it according to the numbers of the *Luoshu*, giving rise to the precelestial eight trigrams. When the precelestial trigrams are overlaid upon the *Hetu*, the medicinal substances and fire phases become brilliantly apparent. This is how the sages perceived the Dao and grasped the mechanism of creation and transformation.

When Qian unites with Li, it is called the yang crucible, with Li dwelling in Qian. When Kun unites with Kan, it is called the yin tripod, with Kan dwelling in Kun. When Zhen meets Li, the dragon emerges from within the fire. When Dui meets Kan, the tiger is born from within the water. These two entities embody the principle of the child producing the mother. As for the moon’s phases—waning in Zhen and waxing in Qian, waning in Xun and setting in Kun—this further reveals the subtleties of the fire phases at the solstices and equinoxes.

The Way of Heaven is vast; only the images of the *Yi* suffice to illuminate it. The Dao of the *Yi* is profound; only the sages suffice to expound it. This Dao was inaugurated by the three lords of antiquity and later elucidated by Master Wei—truly, it arises from the *Hetu*.

Use metal as the embankment, and water enters with ease. The number of metal is fifteen, and the number of water is the same. When tending the furnace to set the weights, let water exceed by five parts. These two are deemed authentic: let the metal’s weight return to its origin. The third does not enter, but fire accompanies it as two. The three substances contain and receive one another, their transformations appearing divine.

Beneath lies the great yang’s darkness, awaiting its moment in silence. First it liquefies, then congeals—this is called the Yellow Chariot. As the years and months draw to a close, nature is undone, and lifespan is harmed. The body becomes ash and dust, resembling the dust on a bright window. When metal and water dwell together, raising the metal draws the water in. Metal is nine, water is six—together they make fifteen. Of these fifteen parts, water claims six, leaving five parts in excess. Metal and water are the true medicine, hence they are called "the two deemed authentic." The nature of wood relies on the essence of metal to form the medicine; the child is concealed within the mother’s womb, so water follows metal inward. Fire is ignited below, and transformation arises. Water, metal, and fire—these three substances are rooted in nature. Wood is governed by metal, metal is drawn by water, and metal is refined by fire. Wood has no role here, so it is said that "the third does not enter," referring to these three.

Yang reaches its extreme and thus liquefies first; yin arises and thus congeals later. It is called the Yellow Chariot because "heaven is dark, earth is yellow," and Kun is earth, the great chariot. At this stage of refinement, yang reaches its limit and yin is born, as Qian gradually transforms into Kun. When the Kun’s way is exhausted, the dragon battles in the dark and yellow, and the body becomes ash and dust—this is the first true manifestation. This passage speaks of yang reaching its limit and yin arising.

Combine and harmonize the refining and blending, then hasten into the gate of crimson. Securely seal their juncture, ensuring it is complete and firm. Let the blazing fire rise from below, its roar ceaseless day and night. Begin with the civil to make it workable, and end with the martial to display it. Observe and tend with utmost care, scrutinizing the adjustments of cold and warmth. Circulate through the twelve nodes, and when each node is complete, examine it closely again. When qi is depleted and life nears its end, cease the work lest the hun and po perish. The color shifts to purple, and suddenly the elixir of return is formed. Grind it into a single pellet, and the spatula’s touch is most divine.

The four images unite to seal Dui and close the gate—thoughtless and effortless—to secure the juncture. As yin is stripped away and yang is born, Kun transforms into Qian. Qian is the great crimson, hence it is said to hasten into the gate of crimson. "Begin with the civil to make it workable" refers to refining the elixir and advancing the fire. Fire cannot be rushed; first, use the civil fire to temper it, ensuring hardness and softness do not resist each other. Once it is workable, advance the fire—this is the initial gentle warmth. At first, ignite the fire to conceive it, called "wild battle." In the middle, nurture it with civil fire, called "irrigation." In the end, use fierce fire to complete it, called "boiling and simmering"—this describes the stages of advancing the fire.

The color shifts to purple, and suddenly the elixir of return is formed. Purple represents Qian, the image of great crimson, the six in the third of *Yi* (Increase), and the top line of Zhen. In the end, it becomes firm. Firmness is Qian, as Zhen transforms into *Qian*.

The *Yi*’s line statement reads: "Inform the duke with a jade tablet." *Yi* (Increase), being pure Qian, thus bears the image of the tablet. Qian is metal, is jade, hence it is called the "knife-jade." Kan and Li unite through the two earths of Wu and Ji to form the body of Qian, which is why the character for "tablet" (*gui*) is composed of two earths. When the fire-phase is complete, Kun transforms into Qian, passing through the Three Palaces to rest the dead *po* and *hun*—this is the second true image.

This chapter speaks of yin at its extreme giving rise to yang, expounding the numbers of the Five Phases with concision and without excess. It takes water to stimulate fire, suddenly extinguishing radiance. The sun and moon press upon each other, ever lingering between darkness and new moon. When water flourishes, Kan encroaches upon yang; when fire wanes, Li’s day grows dim. Yin and yang devour each other, their mutual arousal the natural Way.

This discussion follows the previous chapter’s depiction of the body as ashes and dust, its vital force nearly severed—like the sun and moon pressing upon each other, obscuring their radiance, for Kan-water overcomes Li-fire. Names are given to settle essence; words are chosen to express nature. When metal returns to the origin of nature, it may be called the Elixir of Return. I dare not speak emptily, but emulate the sages’ writings. Ancient records speak of Dragon and Tiger; the Yellow Emperor praised Golden Flower. Huainan refined Autumn Stone; Wang Yang added Yellow Sprout. The worthy can uphold and practice this; the unworthy must not partake. The Way of past and present is one; in conversation, we disclose our plans. Scholars, exert yourselves further, and ponder deeply. The essential words are utterly plain, shining clearly without deceiving me.

Metal’s essence, being utmost yang, returns to water’s nature of utmost yin—this is what is meant by "returning to its root," and thus serving it. Essence is rooted in nature; when nature reverts to its root, it is called the Elixir of Return. This aligns with the middle section’s principle of harmonizing essence with nature. This chapter describes the congealing of the Elixir of Return.

*Cantong Qi*, Scroll One, concludes.

*The Cantong Qi*, Scroll Two
Commentary by Chu Huagu

The firmness of Qian and the softness of Kun unite and embrace.
Yang bestows, yin receives—male and female depend on each other.
Through this, creation unfolds, and essence and qi expand.
Kan and Li crown the head, their radiance spreading forth.
Mysterious and profound, beyond depiction,
The sage measures and orders the foundational mysteries.
The four merge into chaos, entering directly into emptiness.
The sixty hexagrams cycle, woven into a chariot’s frame.
Dragon and horse are harnessed—an enlightened ruler guides the times.
Harmony follows, the path smooth and true.
Deviant ways are perilous, toppling nations and homes.

Qian and Kun, male and female—these are the medicinal substances.
"Yang bestows, yin receives" means Kan governs bestowal, imparting its yang to Li;
Li governs reception, needing yang from Kan—this is what is meant by "uniting and embracing."
"Through this, creation unfolds, and essence and qi expand" means that knowing the way of Kan and Li’s union,
one must also employ the six yang of creation as the fire-timing to enable the dissemination of essence.
"Kan and Li crown the head" means the head is the Dao, and the medicine is the primordial qi.
Primordial qi is the first flourishing of the three mysteries of the primordial beginning—hence it is called "profound darkness" and "mysterious foundation."
"Entering directly into emptiness" means the four images converge, precisely to fulfill the emptiness of Li’s palace.

Following the sixty hexagrams’ fire-timing through the celestial cycle,
if one does not lose the proper moment, there will be harmony without peril.
"Dragon and horse are harnessed" means Zhen is the dragon, Qian the horse—
from the first yang to the sixth yang, the time for firing arrives.

From "Kan and Li crown the head" to "ordering the mysterious foundation" speaks of the medicinal substances.
"The four merge into chaos, entering directly into emptiness" refers to their intercourse.
From "The sixty hexagrams cycle" onward speaks of the fire-timing.

Scholars advancing the fire are like enlightened rulers guiding the times,
thus the analogy of emperors, kings, sovereigns, and lords.
Revering the celestial Dao, assisting yin and yang,
they align the three luminaries to bring great peace.
In grand application, emperors employ it; in personal cultivation, scholars do.
The noble one abides in his chamber; if his words are virtuous,
they resonate a thousand *li* away.
This refers to the lord of ten thousand chariots, dwelling in the nine-fold chamber,
issuing decrees in accord with yin and yang’s rhythms.
Store the vessel, await the time—do not transgress the hexagrams’ months.

*Zhun* uses *zi* and *shen*; *Meng* employs *yin* and *xu*.
The remaining sixty hexagrams each have their own days.
I briefly present the two images, though I cannot exhaust their details.
Establish righteousness, enact punishments—apply benevolence, bestow virtue.
Those who oppose it meet misfortune; those who follow it meet fortune.
Follow the calendar’s decrees, be sincere and focused.
Carefully observe the days and hours, scrutinize the waxing and waning.
In broad terms of lunar phases, the winter solstice is the hexagram *Fu*;
in detailed terms of qi-timing, the winter solstice is *Zhong Fu*.
The hexagram’s line statements begin here—its meaning is profound.

*Wu wu wu geng geng geng*
*Zi xu shen chen yin zi*
For *Zhun*, the first line *gengzi* marks the winter solstice’s first yang;
the sixth line *wuxu* marks the vernal equinox’s bathing.

*Bing bing bing wu wu wu*

chunks.original_text: 下章以先天卦按月出没论火候，故此章先推月之所以生明，由合璧撢持，隐形养魄於晦朔，然后自东北而渐生明也。 勖毕之上， 震出为征。 阳气#9造端，初九潜龙。 阳以三立，阴以八通。 故三日 #10震动，八日 兑行。 九二见龙，和平有明。 三五德就， 乾体乃成。 九三夕惕，亏折神符。 盛衰渐革，终还其初。 此阳火候也。 巽继其统，因际操持。 九四或跃，进退道危。 艮主#11进止，不得瑜除。 二十三日，典守弦期。 九五飞龙，天位加喜。 六五 坤承，结括终始。 蕴养众子，世为类母。 阳数已讫，讫则复起。 推情合性，转而相与。 上九亢龙，战德於野。 用九翩翩，为道规矩#12。 此阴符候也。 循据纵玑，升降上下。 周流六爻，难可察睹#13。 故无常位，为《易》宗祖。 此论上章火候，按《易》卦六爻应环玑升降也。 故无常位，可以见一阳爻动非冬至，非子时，非朔旦，特借是明之尔。 朔旦为 《复》，阳炁始通。 出入无疾，立表微刚。 黄锺建子，兆乃滋彰。 播施柔暖，黎烝#14得常。 《临》炉施条，开路正光。 光耀寝进，日以益长。 丑之大吕，结正低昂。 仰以成 《泰》，刚#15柔并降。 阴阳交接，小往大来。 辐凌於寅，运而趋时。 惭历 《大壮》，使列#16卯门。 榆荚堕落，还归本根。 刑德相负，昼夜始分。 《夬》阴以退，阳升而前。 洗濯羽翮，振索宿尘。 《乾》健盛明，广被四邻。 阳终於巳，仲吕相干。 《娠》始纪绪，履霜最先。 井底寒泉，午为萝宾。 宾服於阴，阴为主人。 《逐》去世位，收敛其精。 怀德埃时#17，栖迟昧冥。 《否》塞#18不通，萌者不生。 阴伸阳讪，没阳姓名。 《观》其权量，察仲秋情。 任畜微稚，老枯复荣。 荠麦芽蘗#19，因冒以生。 《剥》烂支体，消灭其形。 化炁既竭，亡失至神。 道穷则返，归乎 《坤》元。 恒顺地理，承天布宣。 十二月火候反覆发明《屯》、《蒙》二卦之义。 纳甲图生明於东北寅位，故以朔日一言之，《复》起朔旦，知一阳之不在子月、子时明矣。 以上数章并言火侯。 玄幽远眇#20，隔阂相连。 应度育种，阴阳之原。 寥廓恍惚，莫知其端。 先迷失轨，＇后为主君。 无平不陂，道之自然。 变易更盛，消息相因。 终《坤》始《复》，如循连环。 帝王承御，千载#21常存。 阴阳运转，复垢循环，互为其根。 帝王得其道而承天御物，故能千载常存，大其用也。 夫帝王身为三极之主，正五事以格天地之和，顺阴阳以御生杀之柄，故能享国长久，民安国富，皇极建而膺五福也。 黄帝以之而升举，体用兼明也。 否则骄佚亢满，皇极不建，水旱相伐，弦望盈缩，冬暑夏雪，亦罔或克寿矣。 自天子达庶人，得之者昌，失之者亡，故下章继言学士之用。 此章言帝王之用。 将欲养性，延命却期。 审思后末，当虑其先。 人所禀躯，体本一无。 元精云布，因炁#22托初。 阴阳为度，魂魄所居。 阳神日魂，阴神月魄。 魂之与魄，互为室宅。 性主处内，立置鄞鄂。 情主营外，筑垣城郭。 城郭完全，人物乃安。 于斯之时，情合乾坤。 乾动而直，气布精流。 坤静而翕，为道舍庐。 刚施而，退，柔化以滋。 九还七返#23，八归六居。

The following chapter discusses the precelestial trigrams in relation to the monthly waxing and waning of the firing times, so this chapter first traces the moon’s generation of brightness. From the union of the sun and moon, their mutual embrace and support, the hidden form nurtures the *po*-soul in the dark of the moon and its first crescent, then gradually brightens from the northeast. Above *Xu* and *Bi*, *Zhen* emerges as the omen. Yang *qi* initiates its inception, the first nine as the "hidden dragon." Yang is established in threes, yin flows through eights. Thus, on the third day, *Zhen* stirs; on the eighth day, *Dui* moves. The second nine appears as the dragon, harmonious and luminous. When the virtues of three and five are perfected, the body of *Qian* is complete. The third nine watches in evening vigilance, the divine tally waning and fracturing. Flourishing and decline gradually transform, ultimately returning to their origin. Such is the firing time of yang.

*Xun* inherits its lineage, seizing the opportunity to maintain control. The fourth nine leaps or retreats, the Way perilous in advance or withdrawal. *Gen* governs progression and cessation, unable to be polished or removed. On the twenty-third day, one guards the appointed time of the crescent moon. The fifth nine soars as the dragon, the celestial position bringing joy. The sixth five, *Kun* in submission, binds and concludes the beginning and end. It nurtures the multitude of offspring, becoming the mother of all kinds. The yang numbers are exhausted, and upon exhaustion, they arise anew. Following nature and uniting with essence, they turn and join together. The ninth yang, the "exalted dragon," wages virtue in the wilds. Employing the nine, they flutter and become the compass and square of the Dao. Such is the firing time of the yin tally.

Following the pivot of the celestial sphere, ascending and descending, rising and falling, the six lines circulate in revolution—difficult to perceive. Thus, they have no fixed position, forming the ancestral foundation of the *Yi*. This discusses the firing times of the preceding chapter, aligning the six lines of the *Yi* trigrams with the revolving pivot’s ascent and descent. Therefore, having no fixed position reveals that the movement of a single yang line is not confined to the winter solstice, midnight, or the dawn of the new moon—it merely borrows these to illustrate brightness.

The dawn of the new moon is *Fu*, where yang *qi* first flows. Entering and exiting without haste, it establishes the marker of subtle firmness. When the Yellow Bell tunes to *Zi*, omens flourish and manifest. Spreading warmth and softness, the common people thrive in constancy. The *Lin* furnace applies its branches, opening the path of true radiance. The light gradually advances, the days lengthening. The Great Regulator of *Chou* adjusts the balance of high and low. Gazing upward, it completes *Tai*, where firm and yielding descend together. Yin and yang intertwine, the small departing and the great arriving. The spokes converge at *Yin*, moving in accord with the seasons. Progressing through *Da Zhuang*, it commands the gate of *Mao*. Elm pods fall, returning to their root. Punishment and virtue alternate, day and night begin to divide. In *Guai*, yin retreats while yang ascends. Washing and cleansing feathers and wings, it shakes off the dust of slumber. *Qian*’s vigor shines brightly, broadly covering the four neighbors. Yang culminates at *Si*, where the *Zhong Lü* interact. *Shen* begins its lineage, treading frost first. The cold spring at the well’s bottom, *Wu* as the guest of *Luo*. The guest submits to yin, yin becomes the host. *Zhu* departs from its position, gathering its essence. Cherishing virtue and awaiting the time, it rests in obscurity. *Pi* blocks and does not flow, what sprouts cannot grow. Yin extends while yang is slandered, yang’s name erased. *Guan* measures its authority, examining the conditions of mid-autumn. Nurturing the young and tender, the old and withered revive. Shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout, emerging beneath the cover. *Bo* rots the limbs, dissolving its form. When the transforming *qi* is exhausted, the utmost spirit is lost. When the Dao is exhausted, it returns to the origin of *Kun*. Constantly following earth’s principles, it receives Heaven and spreads its decrees.

The twelve months’ firing times, in their cyclical revelation, elucidate the meanings of the *Zhun* and *Meng* trigrams. The *Na Jia* diagram generates brightness in the northeast at the *Yin* position. Thus, speaking of the new moon’s first day, *Fu* arises at dawn, making it clear that the single yang is not confined to the *Zi* month or *Zi* hour. The preceding chapters all discuss firing times.

The profound and distant mysteries interconnect across barriers. Responding to measures and nurturing seeds, they are the origin of yin and yang. Vast and indistinct, none know their beginning. Those who lose the path first become followers; those who grasp it later become rulers. No level ground remains without slope—such is the Dao’s nature. Change and transformation alternate in盛衰, waxing and waning mutually dependent. Ending with *Kun* and beginning with *Fu*, it follows like a linked ring. Emperors and kings who inherit and govern, abiding by this principle, endure for a thousand generations. Yin and yang revolve and cycle, mutually rooting one another. Emperors and kings who grasp this Dao and receive Heaven to govern all things thus endure for millennia, expanding its application.

The emperor’s body serves as the master of the three ultimates, rectifying the five affairs to harmonize Heaven and Earth, following yin and yang to wield the handle of life and death. Thus, they enjoy long reigns, the people at peace and the state prosperous, the royal ultimate established to receive the five blessings. The Yellow Emperor ascended by this principle, embodying both essence and function. Otherwise, arrogance and excess lead to fullness, the royal ultimate unestablished. Flood and drought contend, the moon’s phases wax and wane, winter heat and summer snow—none may attain longevity.

From the Son of Heaven to the common people, those who grasp this prosper; those who lose it perish. Thus, the following chapter discusses the scholar’s application, while this chapter addresses the emperor’s use.

To nurture one’s nature, extend life, and delay the appointed time, one must deliberate on what follows and consider what precedes. The body one receives is fundamentally empty. Primordial essence spreads like clouds, relying on *qi* to establish its beginning. Yin and yang serve as measures, the dwelling of *hun* and *po*. The yang spirit is the sun’s *hun*, the yin spirit the moon’s *po*. *Hun* and *po* mutually serve as dwellings. Nature resides within, establishing boundaries and banks. Emotion operates externally, constructing walls and outer fortifications. When the city walls are complete, people and things find peace. At this time, emotion harmonizes with *Qian* and *Kun*. *Qian* moves directly, *qi* spreading and essence flowing. *Kun* is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s dwelling. The firm advances and retreats, the yielding transforms and nourishes. Nine returns, seven reverses, eight returns, six resides.

chunks.original_text: 男白女赤，金火相拘。 则水定火，五行之初。 上善若水，清而无瑕。 道之形象，真一难图。 变而分布，各自独居。 人之未生，一真而已。 自无而有，变熙以成形体，托形以居魂魄。 日魂本阳神，月魄本阴神。 房日兔反在月中，毕月乌反在日中，坎、离之中爻亦然，互为室宅也。 性为魂，情为魄，性得情以守卫，则不失其初矣。 坎男得乾画，动而施精； 离女得坤画，虚而翕受； 自然九火、七金还元返本，八木、六水归根居源，此以洛书成数论四象也。 金白火赤，故日赤白。 金乃坎男中真阳，火乃离女中真阴，此金、火之二用。 上言七、八、九、六四象，下止言金、水、火者，与三物相含受同义。 四象合体，是为真一，其象不可浴状； 散则五行各得一方之熙而已。 此章言学士之用。 类如鸡子，黑白相扶#24。 纵横一寸，以为始初。 四肢五脏，筋骨乃具。 弥历十月，脱出其胞。 骨弱可卷，肉滑若铅#25。 此论上章道之形象。 阳燧以取火，非日不生光。 方诸非星月，安能得水浆。 二炁#26玄且远，感化尚相通。 何况近存身，切在於心胸。 阴阳配日月，水火为效征。 以物感日月，尚可致水火，况人具真阴、真阳，法日月以娠坎离，何难之有？ 耳目口三宝，固塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 旋曲以豚览，开阖皆合同。 为己之轴辖，动静不竭穷。 离气内营卫，坎乃不用聪。 兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙。 三者既关键，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念以为常。 证难以推移，心专不纵横。 寝寐神相抱，觉寤候存亡。 颜容浸#27以润，骨节益坚强。 辟却众阴邪，然后立正阳。 修之不辍休，庶黑云雨行。 淫淫若春泽，液液象解冰。 从头流达足，究竟复上升。 往来洞无极，怫怫被容中。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄。 芸锄#28宿污秽，细微得调畅。 浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 圣胎已结，周密固闭，守之以无为．'持之以不昧，自然有此功用，自昏而明，由浊而清，从坤体而渐变纯乾也。 前章言圣胎之象。 此章言保养之法。 世人好小卫，不审道浅深。 弃正从邪径，欲速关不通。 犹盲不任仗，聋者听宫商。 投水#29捕雉兔，登山索鱼龙。 植麦欲获黍，运规以求方。 竭力劳精神，终年无见功。 欲知服食法，事约而不烦。 义明不叉释。 太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因。 化为白液，凝而至坚。 金华先倡，有顷之问，解化为水，马齿阑干。 阳乃往和，情性自然。 迫促时阴，拘畜禁门。 慈母养育，孝子报恩。 严父施令，教劲#30子孙。 五行错王，相据以生。 火性销金，金伐木荣。 三五与一，天地至精。 可以口诀，难以书传。 流珠乃离中之汞，性本炎上而飞走，阳金则挟水以制之，妙合而凝矣。 金华先倡，有顷之间，化而为水者，金火既合，火能销金而为水，故下文云火性销金也。 阳乃往和，情性自然者，谓阳情阴性得其类，自然混合，则炁归元海。 漏永息长，故日迫促时阴也。 火不炎上，凡念泯息使鬼道不通，故曰拘畜禁门也。 阳金制木使不得生火，火生祸发必克矣，故下文云金伐木荣也。 离得坤画为母道，居南司夏，以长养为事，故曰慈母养育。 坎得乾画为父道，居北司冬而严凝，以杀为主，以害为恩，故云严父。

The man is white, the woman red—metal and fire restrain each other.
Thus water settles fire, the inception of the Five Phases.
Supreme goodness resembles water, pure and without flaw.
The Dao’s form and image—True Unity is hard to depict.
Transforming and dispersing, each dwells in solitude.
Before a person is born, only True Unity exists.
From nothing to being, transformation flourishes to form the body,
which shelters *hun* and *po* to take residence.

The sun’s *hun* is fundamentally yang spirit; the moon’s *po* is fundamentally yin spirit.
The Chamber’s sun-hare reverses within the moon;
the Net’s moon-crow reverses within the sun.
The middle lines of *Kan* and *Li* are likewise—each serves as the other’s dwelling.
Nature is *hun*; emotion is *po*.
When nature gains emotion as its guardian, it does not lose its origin.

The *Kan* man obtains the *Qian* line, moving to bestow essence;
the *Li* woman obtains the *Kun* line, empty and receptive.
Naturally, nine fires and seven metals return to the origin and revert to the root;
eight woods and six waters return to the source and reside in the spring.
This is the Four Images discussed through the Luo River’s completed numbers.
Metal is white, fire red—hence the sun’s red and white.
Metal is the true yang within *Kan* man; fire is the true yin within *Li* woman—
these are the two functions of metal and fire.
Above speaks of the Four Images—seven, eight, nine, and six—
while below mentions only metal, water, and fire,
which shares the same meaning as the mutual containment of the Three Substances.

The Four Images unite as one body—this is True Unity,
whose image cannot be bathed or described.
When dispersed, the Five Phases each attain one direction’s flourishing.

This chapter speaks of the scholar’s practice.
It is like a chicken’s egg, black and white supporting each other.
A single inch in length and breadth serves as the beginning.
The four limbs and five viscera, sinews and bones, are thus complete.
After ten months pass, it emerges from its womb.
Its bones are weak enough to bend; its flesh is smooth as lead.

This discusses the previous chapter’s Daoist form and image.
A yang burning-mirror gathers fire—without the sun, it does not produce light.
A *fangzhu* vessel does not rely on stars or moon—
how could it obtain water or broth?
The two *qi* are profound and distant, yet their transformations still communicate.
How much more so for what is near and stored within the body,
intimately present in the heart and chest?

Yin and yang pair with the sun and moon; water and fire serve as their effects.
Using objects to interact with the sun and moon,
one can still obtain water and fire.
How much more so for a person possessing true yin and true yang,
who models the sun and moon to conceive *Kan* and *Li*—what difficulty could there be?

The three treasures of ear, eye, and mouth—
firmly seal them, do not let them open or communicate.
The Perfected One lurks in the deep abyss,
floating and roaming while guarding the compass’s center.
Turning and curving to survey, opening and closing all harmonize.
They serve as the axle and linchpin for oneself—
movement and stillness never exhaust.

*Li*’s *qi* internally defends; *Kan* does not employ hearing.
*Dui* unites without speech, few words follow the Primordial Vastness.
Once these three are secured as key mechanisms,
relax the body and dwell in an empty chamber.
Entrust your will to emptiness and nothingness,
taking absence of thought as the constant.
Proof is difficult to shift—focus the mind without distraction.
In sleep, spirit embraces spirit; upon waking, observe presence and absence.
The complexion gradually moistens,
the bones and joints grow ever stronger.
Expelling the host of yin demons,
only then is true yang established.

If cultivation never ceases,
then dark clouds will disperse like rain.
Drizzling like spring’s moisture,
trickling like melting ice.
From the head it flows down to the feet,
ultimately ascending again.
Coming and going, it penetrates the boundless,
permeating the body’s interior.
Reversion is the Dao’s verification; weakness is virtue’s handle.
Weed out long-standing filth,
and the subtle is harmoniously regulated.
The turbid is the path to clarity;
prolonged darkness leads to illumination.

Once the sacred embryo is formed, it is tightly sealed and firmly closed.
Guard it with non-action, hold it without obscurity—
naturally, these functions arise:
from darkness to light, from turbidity to clarity,
from the *Kun* body gradually transforming into pure *Qian*.

The previous chapter spoke of the sacred embryo’s image;
this chapter speaks of the method of nurturing it.

Worldly people favor petty safeguards,
not examining the Dao’s depth or shallowness.
They abandon the correct path to follow deviant trails,
seeking speed but finding the gate blocked.
Like the blind refusing a staff,
or the deaf listening to palace music.
They cast nets in water to catch pheasants and hares,
or climb mountains to seek fish and dragons.
They plant wheat hoping to harvest millet,
or use a compass to seek a square.
Exhausting their strength and laboring their spirit,
throughout the year they see no success.

If you wish to know the method of ingesting and refining:
the affair is simple and not burdensome.
Its meaning is clear and requires no further explanation.

The sun’s flowing pearl constantly seeks to leave.
Suddenly obtaining golden radiance, it turns and relies upon it.
Transforming into white liquid, it congeals into utmost hardness.
The golden radiance first initiates—
after a brief moment, it dissolves and transforms into water,
like horse’s teeth arranged in rows.
Yang then goes to harmonize—nature and emotion naturally unite.
Pressing upon the timely yin,
it is restrained and confined within the gate.
The compassionate mother nurtures; the filial son repays kindness.
The stern father issues commands; the strict teacher instructs descendants.
The Five Phases vie for supremacy, relying on each other to generate.

Fire’s nature melts metal; metal chops down wood’s flourishing.
The Three, Five, and One—these are heaven and earth’s utmost essences.
They can be transmitted orally but are difficult to convey in writing.

The flowing pearl is the mercury within *Li*—
its nature is to blaze upward and flee.
Yang metal then carries water to restrain it,
wondrously uniting and congealing.
The golden radiance first initiates—
after a brief moment, it transforms into water:
once metal and fire unite, fire can melt metal into water,
hence the later statement that fire’s nature melts metal.

“Yang then goes to harmonize—nature and emotion naturally unite”
means that yang’s emotion and yin’s nature find their kindred,
naturally blending so that *qi* returns to the original sea.
The leak is eternally sealed—thus it is said to press upon the timely yin.
Fire does not blaze upward; all thoughts vanish, cutting off the ghostly path—
hence it is said to be restrained and confined within the gate.

Yang metal restrains wood to prevent it from generating fire;
if fire arises and disaster erupts, it will surely be overcome—
hence the later statement that metal chops down wood’s flourishing.

*Li* obtains the *Kun* line as the mother’s way,
residing in the south to govern summer, taking nurturance as its duty—
thus it is called the compassionate mother nurturing.
*Kan* obtains the *Qian* line as the father’s way,
residing in the north to govern winter, taking severity as its essence,
using harm as kindness—thus it is called the stern father.

This chapter speaks of the creative transformations of *Kan* and *Li* in union.
The *zi* hour turns rightward, while *wu* revolves eastward.
*Mao* and *you* stand as boundaries, establishing the two names.
The dragon calls to the tiger; the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence.
Both feed upon each other, each coveting the other’s glory.
Thus they swallow and chew, devouring one another.
When *Yinghuo* guards the west and *Taibai* traverses the heavens,
wherever the killing *qi* descends, what can stand unshaken?
The foxhound guards the rat; the crow and sparrow fear the goshawk.
Each has its function—how dare they make a sound?

*Zi* turns rightward to align with *you*; *wu* revolves eastward to align with *mao*.
When *you* occupies the *wu* position, it is precisely the short-day *Mao* star,
marking the mid-winter moment of the first yang.
At this time, union may be achieved.
The two names refer to the dragon and tiger.
Their mutual swallowing and merging form the image of union.
At first, they covet each other; in the midst, they contend;
in the end, they devour—progressing from shallow to deep,
naturally uniting as one, *Kan* and *Li* in conjugal harmony.

When *Yinghuo* guards the west and *Taibai* traverses the heavens,
*wu* aligns with *you*, and the great fire descends upon *wu*—
precisely the long-day *Huo* star, marking the mid-summer moment of the first yin.
Yin governs the withering and killing; all things retreat and withdraw.
At this time, the yin tally stills the fire.
The adept understands the mechanism of *zi* and *wu*—one yin, one yang—
commanding the metal tiger to restrain the wood dragon,
preventing it from taking flight, like the dog guarding the rat,
like the crow fearing the hawk—each fulfilling its function.

This chapter reveals the subtle principle of yang fire and yin tally.
Without grasping its truth, one speaks in vain,
exhausting family wealth, leaving wife and children hungry and poor.
From ancient times to now, countless have pursued this path,
yet few have met with success, and rarer still are those who achieve it.
Seeking famous medicines far and wide only strays from the Dao.
If one truly encounters it and perceives its beginnings,
comparing like to like and measuring things from start to finish,
then the Way may be attained.

chunks.original_text: 五行相克，更为父母。 母含滋液，父主禀与。 凝精流形，金石不朽。 审专不泄，得为成道。 立竿见影，呼谷传响。 岂不灵哉，天地至象。 若以野葛一寸、巴豆一两，入喉辄僵，不得倪仰。 当此之时，虽周文揲蓍，孔丘占象，扁鹊操针，巫咸扣鼓，安能令苏#34，复起驰走？ 五行相克，谓金见水则金衰，木见火则木克。 更为父母者，木本生火，火乃孕木； 金本生水，水乃胞金是也。 母含滋液，父主禀与，见阳禀阴受注。 河上女，灵而最神。 得火则飞，不见埃尘。 鬼隐龙匿，莫知所存。 将欲制之，黄芽为根。 离为女，位在午野，属周分三河，故日河上女。 立名定象，岂苟乎哉？ 离火生则祸发铃克，谕人之性动，不以正则散乱失其本真，所谓出入莫知其乡也。 如朱砂中有汞，见火则飞走无踪矣。 近取诸身，远取诸物，其理一也。 此与太阳流珠一章同义。 流珠，即女，离中火是 也。 黄芽，即金华，坎中金是也。 此章言药物。 物无阴阳，违天背元#35。 牝鸡#36自卵，其雏不全。 夫何故乎？ 配合未连，三五不交，刚柔离分。 施化之精，天地自然。 犹火动而炎上，水流而润下。 非有师道#37，使其然者复改。 观夫雌雄，交垢#38之时； 刚柔相结，而不可解； 得其节符，非有工巧，以制御之。 若男生而伏，女偃其躯； 禀乎胞胎，受炁元初； 非徒生时，着而见之； 及其死也； 及其死也； 亦复效之。 此非父母，教令其然，本在交姤，制定始先。 言独阴不成亦出自然，独阳不成。 坎离之合，亦出自然，非人力强使之然也。 坎男为月，离女为日。 日以施德，月以舒光。 月受日化，体不亏伤。 阳失其契，阴侵其明。 晦朔薄蚀，奄冒相包。 阳消其形，阴陵生灾#39。 男女相须，含吐以滋。 雄雌交#40。 以类相求。 金化为水，水性周章。 火化为土，水不得行。 故男动外施，女静#41内藏。 溢度过节，为女所拘。 魄以检魂，不得淫奢。 不寒不暑，进退合时。 各得其和，俱吐证符。 以日月、男女、雌雄明配合之象，失其符则为薄蚀也。 金化为水，水性同章者，金中生水，欲克离火，然离火生土．又克水，使水降伏不动也。 男动外施，女动内藏者，与阳禀阴受同义。 魄以检魂，情卫性，金制木也。 不得淫奢者，性不化情也。 不寒不暑，进退合时者，不失阴阳分至之候，进火息符，皆合节度，故各吐证符。 丹砂木精，得金乃并。 金水合处，木火为侣。 四者混沌，列为龙虎。 龙阳数奇，虎阴数偶。 肝青为父，肺白为母。 肾黑为子，脾黄为祖。 三物一家，都归戊已。 四象合而归戊己，见前注。 已上并论交姤。 刚柔迭兴，更历分部。 龙西虎东，建纬卯酉。 刑德并会，相见欢喜。 刑主伏杀，德主生起。 二月榆死，□临於卯。 八月麦生，天呈据酉。 子南午北，互为纲纪。 九一之数，终则复始。 含元虚危，播精於子。 阳长则阴消，阴消则阳长，刚柔迭兴也。 二十八宿主十二辰，遍历十二 分野，更历分部也。 龙位东而临西，虎位西而临东，卯酉相加，故日龙西虎东也。 《龙虎经》云：南北为经，则知卯酉为纬矣。 故日建纬卯酉。 卯为德，主生； 酉为刑，主杀； 卯酉相加，生中有杀，杀中有生。 故二月检落，戌中辛临乙也；

The Five Phases restrain one another, each in turn becoming father and mother.
The mother contains the nourishing fluid, the father governs bestowal and endowment.
Essence congeals and form flows—metal and stone do not decay.
With careful focus and no leakage, one may attain the Way of completion.
Erect a pole and see its shadow; call into the valley and hear its echo—
how can this not be numinous? It is the supreme image of Heaven and Earth.

Yet if one takes a mere inch of *yege* or a single ounce of *badou*,
swallowing brings instant collapse, leaving one unable to turn or lift.
At such a moment, even if King Wen were casting milfoil stalks,
Confucius interpreting omens, Bian Que wielding his needles,
or Wu Xian beating his drum—
how could they revive the fallen or restore them to swift movement?

The Five Phases restraining one another means:
when metal encounters water, metal weakens;
when wood encounters fire, wood is overcome.
"Each in turn becoming father and mother" refers to:
wood originally giving birth to fire, and fire then gestating wood;
metal originally giving birth to water, and water then nurturing metal.

The mother contains the nourishing fluid, the father governs bestowal and endowment—
this shows yang endowing and yin receiving.
The Maiden by the River is numinous and most divine.
When she obtains fire, she takes flight, leaving no trace of dust.
Ghosts conceal themselves, dragons hide—none know where they abide.
Should one wish to restrain her, the Yellow Sprout becomes the root.

*Li* is the Maiden, positioned in the *wu* wilds,
belonging to the Zhou division of the Three Rivers—hence "Maiden by the River."
Is the naming and fixing of images done carelessly?
When the fire of *Li* is born, calamity arises and restraint is broken—
this illustrates how human nature, when stirred,
if not aligned with the proper, scatters and loses its original truth,
so that "entering and exiting, none know its direction."
Like mercury within cinnabar—when exposed to fire, it flees without a trace.

Whether drawing near from the body or far from things,
the principle is one and the same.
This aligns with the chapter on "The Flowing Pearl of Great Yang."
The Flowing Pearl is the Maiden, the fire within *Li*.
The Yellow Sprout is Golden Flower, the metal within *Kan*.

This chapter speaks of medicinal substances.
Things devoid of yin and yang defy Heaven and contravene the Origin.
A hen hatching alone—her chicks will not be whole.
Why is this so?
The union was not complete; the Three and Five did not merge;
hard and soft remained apart.
The essence of transformation is the natural process of Heaven and Earth—
like fire rising when stirred, like water flowing downward to moisten.
It is not some mastered method that compels this, only to change it later.

Observe the mating of male and female in their union—
hard and soft intertwine, inseparable.
When the proper timing aligns, it is not through craft or artifice that they are governed.
When a boy is born, he lies prone; when a girl is born, she lies supine—
endowed in the womb, receiving qi from the primal beginning.
This is not merely visible at birth;
even in death, they replicate it.
It is not that parents teach them to do so—
the pattern was set at the moment of union, determined from the very start.

To say that solitary yin cannot complete, or solitary yang cannot complete,
is also natural.
The union of *Kan* and *Li* likewise arises naturally,
not through human effort forcing it to be so.
*Kan* as the male is the moon; *Li* as the female is the sun.
The sun bestows virtue; the moon unfurls its light.
The moon receives the sun’s transformation, its body unharmed.
If yang loses its bond, yin encroaches upon its brightness.
At the dark and new moons, they press close, enveloping one another.
Yang’s form diminishes; yin’s encroachment brings calamity.

Male and female depend on one another, inhaling and exhaling to nourish.
Male and female unite in congress, seeking their kind.
Metal transforms into water, water’s nature circulating freely.
Fire transforms into earth, blocking water’s flow.
Thus the male moves and bestows outwardly; the female is still and stores within.
If overflowing exceeds the proper measure, she becomes constrained.
The *po* restrains the *hun*, preventing excess and extravagance.
Neither cold nor hot, advancing and retreating in timely accord—
each attains harmony, both emitting confirming signs.

With the sun and moon, male and female, yin and yang—
the image of their union is made clear.
Losing their bond results in obscuration and eclipse.
"Metal transforms into water, water’s nature circulating freely" means:
water born within metal seeks to overcome the fire of *Li*,
but the fire of *Li* generates earth, which in turn overcomes water,
causing water to submit and remain still.

"Male moves and bestows outwardly; female is still and stores within"—
this shares the same meaning as yang endowing and yin receiving.
"The *po* restrains the *hun*"—emotion guards nature, metal restrains wood.
"Not permitting excess and extravagance"—nature is not transformed by emotion.
"Neither cold nor hot, advancing and retreating in timely accord"—
not losing the solar terms of yin and yang’s division,
advancing fire and ceasing tally all align with proper measure,
thus each emits confirming signs.

Cinnabar, the essence of wood, unites with metal to merge.
Where metal and water combine, wood and fire become companions.
The four intermingle in chaos, arrayed as dragon and tiger.
The dragon’s yang number is odd; the tiger’s yin number is even.
The liver, green, is the father; the lungs, white, are the mother.
The kidneys, black, are the child; the spleen, yellow, is the ancestor.
Three things form one household, all returning to *wu* and *ji*.

The four images unite and return to *wu* and *ji*—see previous notes.
The above all discuss union.
Hard and soft alternate in ascent, traversing the divisions in turn.
The dragon in the west, the tiger in the east—
establishing the weft at *mao* and *you*.
Punishment and virtue converge, meeting in joy.
Punishment governs submission and killing; virtue governs generation and ascent.

In the second month, the elm withers as *yin* approaches *mao*.
In the eighth month, wheat sprouts as Heaven’s *yang* occupies *you*.
North at *zi*, south at *wu*—each serves as the other’s guiding principle.
The numbers nine and one cycle endlessly, beginning anew.
Embracing the primal in *xu* and *wei*, scattering essence at *zi*.
When yang grows, yin diminishes; when yin diminishes, yang grows—
hard and soft alternate in ascent.
The twenty-eight constellations govern the twelve earthly branches,
traversing the twelve celestial divisions—this is "traversing the divisions in turn."

The dragon’s position is east yet faces west; the tiger’s position is west yet faces east—
*mao* and *you* intersect, hence "the dragon in the west, the tiger in the east."
The *Dragon-Tiger Classic* states: "North and south form the warp,"
thus we know *mao* and *you* form the weft—hence "establishing the weft at *mao* and *you*."
*Mao* is virtue, governing generation;
*you* is punishment, governing killing.
*Mao* and *you* intersect—within generation lies killing, within killing lies generation.
Thus in the second month, the elm falls as *xin* in *xu* approaches *yi*...

the noble man’s fine match.

The male does not dwell alone,
nor does the female reside in solitude.
The Dark Warrior—tortoise and serpent—
coil and intertwine in mutual support.
Thus it is made clear: yin and yang,
in the end, must depend on one another.

Were two women to share a chamber,
their beauty as sisters,
though Su Qin were to mediate,
Zhang Yi to broker the match,
their eloquence sharp as blades,
their words sweet and persuasive,
their hearts laid bare in perfect harmony,
urging them to wed—
yet with hair grown brittle and teeth decayed,
they would never truly know one another.

If the ingredients are not of the same kind,
their names and categories disparate,
their measures mismatched,
their principles lost—
though the Yellow Emperor himself tend the furnace,
the Great One descend to his seat,
the Eight Lords invoke and refine,
Huainan grasp the flame,
pavilions raised and altars exalted,
steps and terraces of jade,
unicorn jerky and phoenix cured meat offered,
registers held in long obeisance,
prayers and petitions to the gods,
pleas to the mournful dead,
bathing and fasting in purification,
all in hope of some result—
it would be no different than mending a cauldron with glue,
or smearing a wound with bronze,
adding ice to frost,
or curing heat with boiling water.
Flying turtles and dancing serpents
would only appear more perverse.

This speaks of yin relying on yang,
reiterating the opening meaning of *Guan Ju*:
the union of male and female.

*Thus concludes the middle scroll of the* Zhouyi Cantong Qi. *(The character* 喻 *was originally* 论*, emended here according to the sense of the text.)*

chunks.original_text: 惟昔圣贤，怀玄抱真。 服炼九鼎隐沦。 含精养神，通德三元。 精液凑理，筋骨致坚。 众邪辟除，正气#1长存。 累积长久，变形而仙。 忧悯后生，好道之伦。 随傍风采，指画古文。 着为图籍，开示后昆。 露见枝条，隐藏本根。 托号诸石，覆冒众文。 学者得之，韫匮#2终身。 子继父业，孙踵祖先。 传世迷惑，竟无见闻。 遂使宦者不遂，农夫失芸#3，商人弃货，志士家贫。 吾甚伤之，定录斯文。 字约易思，事省不烦。 披列其条。 实核可观。 分两有数，因而相循。 故为乱辞思，孔窍其门。 智者审思．以意参焉。 九鼎者，金鼎也。 九在洛书成数为金，九为乾金阳数。 鼎者，金之室也。 此章首言药。 法象莫大乎天地兮，互沟#4数万里。 河鼓临星纪兮，人民皆惊骇。 晷景妄前却兮，九年被凶咎。 皇上览阮之兮，王者退自改。 关键有低昂兮，害黑遂奔走。 江淮之枯竭兮，水流注於海。 天地之雌雄兮，徘徊子与午。 寅申阴阳祖兮，出入复终始。 循斗而招摇兮，执衡定元纪#5。 鼎之与器，法象乾坤。 互沟者，阴阳界限，如鼎器交互相接之所，言金木问隔如天地相去何止数万里之远，所以使之合者道也。 河鼓临星纪者，火临金位而逼金也。 谓离当居下，而反居上，离性炎上，水火未济，不能翕受坎中乾金，违龙低虎昂之旨，失其关键，故刚柔抗行，不相涉入，使真药奔散四出，故日人民皆惊骇。 人民，谕药物也。 《悟真篇》虎称岩头龙称海，底火在下金在上也。 前篇云炎火张於下，又日下有太阳无，其法度高下显然可见矣。 晷景妄前却者，晷景乃进火退火时刻也。 若进退失节，不当前而妄前，不当却而妄却，则九年之水为凶咎矣。 此即二至改度，二分纵横，则水旱相伐，山崩地裂是也。

Here follows the translation:

Only the sages and worthies of old
embraced the mysterious and held fast to the true.
They ingested and refined the Nine Cauldrons, concealed in reclusion,
contained essence and nurtured spirit,
communed with virtue through the Three Origins.
Essence and fluid converged in the textures,
sinews and bones grew firm.
All perverse influences were dispelled,
and the upright qi endured ever after.
Through long and patient accumulation,
they transformed their forms and ascended as immortals.

Moved by compassion for later generations,
those who loved the Dao,
they followed the winds of influence,
traced and sketched the ancient texts,
composed them into illustrated works,
and revealed them to posterity.
Yet they exposed only the branches,
concealing the root.
They entrusted them to various stones,
veiled them beneath layers of texts.
Scholars who obtained them
hoarded them in secrecy all their lives.
Sons inherited their fathers’ work,
grandsons followed their ancestors’ path.
Transmitted through generations in confusion,
none ever gained true insight.
Thus officials failed in their careers,
farmers neglected their plowing,
merchants abandoned their goods,
and men of resolve fell into poverty.

I grieve deeply for this,
and so set down these writings in order.
The words are concise and easy to ponder,
the matters few and free of clutter.
I lay out their principles in sequence,
substantial and verifiable to behold.
Weights and measures are precise,
each following in due succession.

Thus I compose these disordered verses,
opening the gates through their apertures.
Let the wise examine and reflect,
and weigh them with their own understanding.

The Nine Cauldrons are cauldrons of metal.
In the *Luoshu*, nine is the completed number of metal,
and nine is the yang number of Qian-metal.
The cauldron is the chamber of metal.

This chapter first speaks of the medicine.
No model is greater than Heaven and Earth—
their mutual boundary spans tens of thousands of miles.
When the River Drum approaches the Stellar Enclosure,
the people are all seized with terror.
The shadow’s reckless advance and retreat
bring nine years of calamity.
The August Emperor, beholding the portents of Ruin,
the king retreats and reforms himself.
The key has its rises and falls,
and the black harm flees in haste.
When the Yangzi and Huai run dry,
their waters pour into the sea.

The female and male of Heaven and Earth
revolve between *zi* and *wu*.
*Yin* and *shen* are the ancestors of yin and yang,
issuing and entering, returning to their beginning.
Following the Dipper’s handle in its sweep,
grasping the balance to fix the primal order.

The cauldron and the vessel
model Qian and Kun.
The mutual boundary is the division of yin and yang,
like the place where cauldron and vessel join and meet.
It speaks of the separation between metal and wood,
as distant as Heaven and Earth—
how many tens of thousands of miles apart?
Only the Dao can bring them together.

When the River Drum approaches the Stellar Enclosure,
fire presses upon the metal position, threatening metal.
This means *li* should reside below,
yet instead it rises above.
The nature of *li* is to flame upward,
water and fire unbalanced,
unable to embrace the Qian-metal within *kan*,
violating the principle of the dragon’s descent and the tiger’s ascent.
Losing the key,
hard and soft resist each other,
failing to interpenetrate.
The true medicine scatters in all directions—
hence the people are seized with terror.
The people symbolize the medicinal substances.

The *Wuzhen Pian* says:
“The tiger is called the cliff’s head, the dragon the sea.”
The fire lies below, the metal above.
The preceding section states:
“The blazing fire spreads below,”
and again:
“Below, there is no Great Yang.”
The method’s highs and lows are clearly evident.

When the shadow recklessly advances or retreats,
the shadow marks the timing of advancing and withdrawing fire.
If the rhythm is lost—
advancing when it should not,
retreating when it should not—
then nine years of water bring calamity.
This is like the solstices altering their degrees,
the equinoxes shifting their alignments,
causing floods and droughts to contend,
mountains to collapse and the earth to split.

The sovereign, recognizing these errors and correcting them, aligns the lows and highs of the pivotal mechanism. The five *qi* follow their proper sequence, and the pernicious, rebellious *qi* flee far away. The waters of the Yangtze and Huai naturally flow to pay homage to the sea, and the medicinal substances return to their origin.

The Heaven and Earth’s female and male—lingering between *zi* and *wu*—are the true yin of *kan*-man and the true yang of *li*-woman. The *yin* and *yang* ancestors of *yin* and *shen* refer to the *yin* tally and *yang* fire originating in *yin* and *shen*. In the *Na Jia* diagram, the moon emerges from *zhen*-*geng*, where the first yang line stirs and the *yang* fire originates; the moon wanes in *xun*-*xin*, where the first yin line transforms and the *yin* tally originates. In the *Prior Heaven* trigrams, *zhen* occupies the *yin* position and *xun* the *shen* position, thus establishing the two solstices. Hence, *yin* and *shen* are the ancestors of *yin* and *yang*. The moon emerges from *yin* and enters *shen*, entering and then re-emerging—thus its rising and setting complete the cycle. Following the turning of the Dipper’s handle, the *Na Jia* fire phases are determined, hence it is said: “grasping the balance to fix the primordial纪.”

The *Yuan* Star Lord and *Ji* Star Lord are star names within the Dipper. When the *River Drum* approaches the *Star Ji*, the people are seized with terror—this speaks of failing to adhere to the method’s measures, causing the medicinal substances to scatter. When the shadow recklessly advances or retreats, nine years bring calamity—this speaks of not following the fire phases, causing water to lose its nature. The pivotal mechanism has lows and highs—this speaks of correcting errors, aligning with the method’s measures, causing pernicious *qi* to flee and disasters to dissipate. The Yangtze and Huai’s drying up, their waters flowing into the sea—this speaks of adhering to the method’s measures, following the fire phases, and the medicinal substances returning to their origin. *Zi* and *wu* refer to the medicinal substances; *yin* and *shen* refer to the fire phases. Following the Dipper’s turning, *yin* and *shen* determine the morning and evening of *pi* and *tai*. This should be carefully pondered.

This chapter elaborates on the method’s measures for intercourse and concludes with the fire phases.

Rising and toasting upon the *Fan* Mountain—
the blazing fire spreads below.
The White Tiger leads the way—
the Azure Fluid harmonizes behind.
The Vermilion Bird soars and plays,
its flying radiance displaying five hues.
Suddenly, it encounters a net cast—
pressed down, it cannot rise.
Its wailing cries are mournful,
like an infant longing for its mother.
Overturned and plunged into boiling water,
its feathers and wings are crushed and broken.
Before half the clepsydra’s mark has passed,
the dragon’s scales stir restlessly.
Five-colored images dazzle,
transforming without constant master.
The cauldron seethes and surges,
violently surging without cease.
Jumbled and layered in piles,
like interlocking canine teeth.
Its form like midwinter ice,
railing-like stalactites sprout.
Towering and tangled,
crossing and propping one another.

When yin and yang find their match,
they settle in tranquil mutual embrace.
The Green Dragon dwells in *Fang*-six—
spring blossoms in *zhen*-east-*mao*.
The White Tiger resides in *Xu*-seven—
autumn’s awns in *dui*-west-*you*.
The Vermilion Bird is in *Zhang*-two—
true yin in *li*-south-*wu*.
All three come to pay homage,
their families forming a chorus of kinship.
Originally but two substances—
in the end, they become three and five.
Three, five, and one together—
all gather in one place.

Refine them according to the above method,
and the days’ count also follows accordingly.

Metal, having overcome wood, further restrains it with water, so the Vermilion Bird, as if caught in a net, cannot take flight. The *li* fire, unable to generate, returns to *zhen* wood—hence the dragon’s scales shimmer in five colors. *Zhen* is the dragon, *li* is radiance.

Canine teeth, winter ice, railings, and stalactites—all are true images. I have therefore compiled and recorded anew, filling gaps and omissions, refining what is profound and obscure, linking threads to ensure coherence, aligning intent and purpose without deviation. Thus I compose this work, naming it *The Five Phases’ Mutual Generation*, wherein the nature and essence of the great *Yi* are fully revealed.

The Five Positions harmonize, each with its proper union:
*Yi* floats as stone, *ding* patterns with civil fire, *ji* governs matter, *xin* embodies worldly silver, *gui* is true lead—three woods, two fires, five earths, four metals, one water.
*Jia* sinks as stone, *bing* blazes with martial fire, *wu* refines the medicine, *geng* embodies worldly gold, *ren* is true mercury.
This is the *Luoshu*’s primordial numbering.

The great *Yi*’s nature and essence each adhere to their measure. The teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, when examined, may be applied. The work of furnace and fire has true foundation: the Three Ways emerge from One, all following the same path. The learning of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi arises from the great *Yi*; the discourse on furnace and fire is grounded in the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. These three all derive from the *Yi*, each addressing nature and essence alone.

Branches, stems, blossoms, leaves—fruit hangs in abundance. Yet the root remains primary, unchanging in its original state. What is spoken in sincerity is precise and without error. It is like the tree that in spring sends forth stems and branches, by summer opens blossoms and spreads leaves, and by autumn bears fruit—yet the source of its growth lies in the root. Thus it is said: the root remains primary, unchanging in its original state. This means it does not lose its inherent nature.

From the flourishing of *Tai* to the purity of *Qian*, the root lies in the *Fu* hexagram, founded at the winter solstice. The wondrous work of return and reversal arises from the single yang of midnight. What the sages and perfected ones kept secret—scholars know only the function of the single yang, yet *Lin*, *Tai*, *Zhuang*, and *Guai* transform naturally, without need of human effort. Thus I single out the image of the midwinter season to reveal it.

This passage connects to what follows, likening the root to the winter solstice. Thus it says: “Like the midwinter season, bamboo and trees are all broken and harmed.” For the stems and branches of spring become the blossoms and leaves of summer, and the blossoms and leaves of summer become the fruit of autumn—all arising from the midwinter’s breaking and harming. The primordial flourishing lies hidden in the root, receiving its generation at the first return of the single yang.

Like the midwinter season, bamboo and trees are all broken and harmed.
Assisting yang, merchants and travelers halt; the lord deeply conceals himself.
Following the season’s rhythm, mouths close and words cease.
The Dao of Heaven is vast and boundless; the Great Mystery has no form.
The empty and still cannot be seen; their boundaries dissolve and vanish.
Pursuing error leads only to ruin; speech returns to self-defeat.
Distinguish and clarify these Four Images to enlighten later generations of the blind.

Paired with ingestion, yin and yang are arrayed.

Three paths are laid out, their branches and stems interconnected.

Not merely piling up lines, this text achieves harmony.
It holds true substance; its rough outlines are worth observing.
If I were to expound falsely, I would only incur redundancy.
Thus I name it *Cantong Qi*, revealing its subtleties in brief.
Few words convey great meaning; descendants should heed it.

When Tang faced adversity, drought and flood divided the land.

The virtuous carry one another’s burdens—secure and stable, they may attain long life.
